snippet: Experts said the Sri Lankans’ saga shows the subjective nature of immigration enforcement and raises questions about how refugees who cooperate in human trafficking cases are treated.
abstract: Five Sri Lankan men who paid $55,000 each to be smuggled into America have been in immigration jails since late 2010; men cooperated with the FBI in an investigation of their smugglers, which they believed would work in their favor as their cases made their way through immigration courts; experts say the cases highlight the subjective nature of immigration enforcement.
lead_paragraph: Experts said the Sri Lankans’ saga shows the subjective nature of immigration enforcement and raises questions about how refugees who cooperate in human trafficking cases are treated.

headline.main: Tamils’ Smuggling Journey to U.S. Leads to Longer Ordeal: 3 Years of Detention
headline.print_headline: Tamils’ Smuggling Journey to U.S. Leads to Longer Ordeal: 3 Years of Detention
